monthly_revenue.farm_vs_events: Farm produces ~2x events revenue, BUT events have much better profit margins
monthly_revenue.net_profit: Events net profit higher than farm despite lower revenue
monthly_revenue.note: Farm is revenue anchor, events are profit driver

types: On-farm: hosting people, farm-to-table meals, workshops
Off-farm: Taking 'farm experience' to beaches, hotels, Sahel (coast)
Education: Planting, carpentry, pottery, hands-on nature activities
Entertainment: Traditional farm meals, nature connection

previous_career.focus: Youth employment, technical education, matchmaking jobs, decent work
previous_career.masters: Sustainable Development, thesis on waste management
previous_career.reason_for_leaving: Want to try something entrepreneurial, felt timing was right before financial commitments

career_transition_decision.label: fulfilled_no_regrets
evidence: Best decision I made is changing my life
I deserve this after all the hustle
At 30, felt it was right timing before financial commitments
Loved ILO work but felt my capacity was bigger

development_sector_critique.label: realistic_disillusionment
evidence: Development work: 'Is my time and effort and money equal to this impact? Not at all'
Issue is bigger than my manager, their manager, bureaucracy
Things become formalities, not actual impact
Felt constrained by organizational politics

mid_stage_challenges.label: struggling_but_committed
evidence: Beginning stage is hard, but mid-stage is ALSO very hard
People think beginning is difficult, but continuing is equally difficult
Need to find team that can continue with you
Constant hiring/turnover challenges
Can't take break, can't step away

climate_change_threat.label: worried_strategic_challenge
evidence: Water salinity increasing due to climate change
Farm productivity decreasing, losses increasing
Need new well or desalination ($$$)
Big challenge, need to think of options
Long-term existential risk to farm

humenow_program.label: very_positive_network_focused
evidence: Most valuable: Network of people with common interests
Women empowerment & entrepreneurship focus was inspiring
Examples of women juggling family + business = most inspiring
Appreciated mix of stages (6-year veteran + beginners)
Group was 'delicious' (enjoyable)

explicit_needs.evidence: Climate change → salinity increase → farm productivity declining. Need: new well OR desalination system
explicit_needs.urgency: Medium-term (5 years) but planning needed now

explicit_needs.evidence: Constant team churn. Hiring, people leave, re-hiring cycle. 'Need team that can continue with me.' Currently Iman doing everything
Currently doing all accounting herself (time-consuming). Outsourced service no longer enough at current scale. Needs full-time accountant but first needs to organize books
explicit_needs.note: Similar to other mid-stage entrepreneurs - outgrew basic outsourced accounting

implied_needs.inference: Dual revenue model working but climate threat looming. Needs strategic planning: invest more in farm resilience OR pivot more to events-only model?
Already doing off-farm events (beach, hotels, Sahel). This could scale significantly without land constraints. Opportunity to franchise 'farm experience'
Offered to mentor future HumeNow cohorts, facilitate groups. Wants to give back. Values education/training from ILO background

core_values.evidence: Left ILO despite loving work because impact didn't match effort. 'Issue is bigger - bureaucracy, formalities.' Chose entrepreneurship for direct impact
Masters in Sustainable Development, thesis on waste management. Organic farming. Nature connection workshops. Environmental focus throughout
ILO background in technical education. Farm workshops: planting, carpentry, pottery. 'Hands-on' emphasized. Education + entertainment model
Turned down loans and partnerships: 'I'm not ready psychologically for partners. Need strong financial structure first. Would rather baby steps, fully in control'
HumeNow women focus was inspiring. Sees women juggling family + business as 'most inspiring.' But: 'I don't care about gender, it's about doing change'

interest_level.note: Cooperative model not explicitly discussed in this interview
interest_level.inference: Likely interested but would want autonomy preserved. Very cautious about partnerships/commitments at current stage

most_valuable: Network of people with common interests
Mix of experience levels (6-year veteran + beginners)
Exposure to different models and thinking
what_worked: Mentorship matching based on needs assessment
design_suggestions_for_bloom: Visit projects in person for inspiration
Needs assessment before mentoring (not generic group training)
One-on-one mentoring more valuable than group sessions at mid-stage
Sector-specific groupings helpful but not mandatory

readiness_assessment.reasoning: Established dual-revenue business model (farm + events), strong values, ILO professional background. BUT: Mid-stage challenges (team churn, accounting needs), climate threat (salinity), cautious about partnerships. Perfect example of 'mid-stage entrepreneur' who needs different support than early-stage. Good pilot candidate if cooperative addresses mid-stage specific needs.

support_needed: Brand scaling for off-farm events model
Long-term strategic planning (farm vs events focus)
recommendation.unique_value: ILO development sector expertise, mid-stage entrepreneur advocate, dual revenue model (farm anchor + events profit), Egypt representation, women entrepreneurship
recommendation.special_note: Iman represents THE mid-stage entrepreneur Bilal + Hany discussed: past ideation, executing well, but facing scaling challenges. Exactly who needs support but often overlooked for 'sexy early-stage ideas.'

mid_stage_entrepreneur_support_cohort.description: Iman (+ Bilal + Hany) all identified: mid-stage entrepreneurs need different support than early-stage

problem.current: Most accelerators focus on early-stage (ideas, validation)
problem.gap: Mid-stage entrepreneurs (executing, revenues, but struggling with systems/team/scaling) are underserved
problem.iman_quote: Beginning stage is hard, but mid-stage is ALSO very hard. People think beginning is difficult, but continuing is equally difficult

solution_design.target: Entrepreneurs with revenue, product-market fit, but facing:
support_model: Peer support from other mid-stage founders

mid_stage_entrepreneur_support_cohort.action_required: Bilal designs mid-stage entrepreneur cohort, invites Iman + similar

farm_experience_franchise_model.description: Iman already doing off-farm events (beach, hotels, Sahel). Higher margins than farm. Could scale significantly

current_state.off_farm: Taking farm experience to other venues (scalable)

opportunity.model: Brand 'Hazel Farm Experience' as scalable events business
opportunity.venues: Hotels, resorts, beaches, corporate retreats, schools
opportunity.offering: Hands-on nature workshops (planting, pottery, carpentry) + traditional meals
opportunity.advantage: Not land-constrained, higher margins, mitigates climate risk

farm_experience_franchise_model.action_required: Business model workshop: Shift from 'farm that does events' to 'events brand anchored by farm'

water_salinity_climate_adaptation.description: Climate change causing water salinity increase. Farm productivity declining. Need long-term solution
options: New well (expensive, risk of salinity again)
Pivot more to events, less to farm production
water_salinity_climate_adaptation.strategic_question: Is farm the business or the anchor? Should Iman double down on farm resilience or shift to events-primary model?
water_salinity_climate_adaptation.action_required: Strategic planning session + climate adaptation expertise

ilo_bloom_partnership_employment_trainin.description: Iman has 4 years ILO experience (employment, technical education). Could bridge Bloom <> ILO for employment programs

specifics.iman_background: Employment specialist, youth training, matchmaking, decent jobs
specifics.potential: Bloom entrepreneurs as employment creators, ILO as funder/partner

ilo_bloom_partnership_employment_trainin.action_required: Iman introduces Bloom to ILO Egypt/regional office

key_quotes.on_career_transition: At 30 years old, I said I want to try something else. I love what I do but I feel my capacity is a little bigger. And also the more you grow in development and funding sector, you know more that it's very nice but it's not as impactful as you think
key_quotes.on_impact_vs_bureaucracy: I started asking: Is my time and effort and money funded really equal to this impact? Not at all. Because the issue is bigger than my manager, their manager. There are political things, bureaucratic things. Things become formalities more than actual [impact]
key_quotes.on_mid_stage_difficulty: Beginning stage is hard, but THIS stage is also very hard. People think the beginning is difficult, but continuing is equally difficult. You need to find a team that can continue with you. This is REALLY hard. Every little while there's team turnover, hire someone, someone leaves, need someone else
key_quotes.on_growth_philosophy: I don't want to grow fast. I want to grow slowly. And even though I want to grow, I don't want loans or partnership commitments. Psychologically I'm not ready for partners. I need to have very strong financial structure before I consider partners. I would rather baby steps where I'm in full control
key_quotes.on_best_decision: Best decision I made is changing my life to be entrepreneur. I deserve this. After all the hustle and all the hard work, I deserve it. Because at the end there's a difference between 'job' and 'investment'
key_quotes.on_women_but_not_only: The inspiring thing about women is they're doing one thing while having family and children and able to do this. So that's most inspiring. But for me personally I don't care - women, men, any gender - in the end we're doing change
key_quotes.on_climate_threat: Climate change and water quality - this is a big challenge now. I'm facing water salinity level increased a lot. This means I have to invest in a new well, and that's a big budget. And it's also a risk because the well might also have salinity again with time

growth_edges: Can't step away from business ('no break possible')
meta_insights.unique_contribution: THE mid-stage entrepreneur example. ILO development sector background. Dual revenue model (production + experiences). Egypt representation. Climate adaptation advocate. Women entrepreneurship (pragmatic, not identity-focused).
meta_insights.special_status: Iman embodies Bilal + Hany's insight: mid-stage entrepreneurs need different support. She's past ideation, executing well, but facing scaling pains. Exactly the underserved segment that deserves focus.
